title: Crystal Palace secure early £22.5m windfall from Aaron Wan-Bissaka's Man United move
text:
Crystal Palace have pocketed a £22.5million windfall ahead of the January transfer window, after striking a deal with an Australian bank.

The Eagles have negotiated to receive money owed to them by Manchester United upfront, with Australian bank Macquarie purchasing the loan.

United, who still owe the money following the summer transfer of full-back Aaron Wan-Bissaka, will now make the payment to Macquarie, as report the Evening Standard.

Crystal Palace have received £22.5m from the Aaron Wan-Bissaka transfer after striking a deal

Palace sold the 21-year-old to United in a club record £50m deal in the summer, as chairman Steve Parish went about outlining his redevelopment plans for the club.

Palace are focusing on further solidifying their Premer League status, while making a £100m redevelopment of the main stand at their Selhurst Park stadium.

The move to agree a deal with a large scale bank is now becoming more and more commonplace in football.

Wan-Bissaka became Palace's record sale in summer, after completing his £50m United move

Palace are investing for the future with a redevelopment of the main stand at Selhurst planned

Palace's tactic mirrors that of Bournemouth, who secured loans against the instalments owed on the deals for Tyrone Mings and Lys ­Mousset.

Elsewhere in the Premier League Leicester also followed the same procedure with Riyad Mahrez, with both also looking to develop their infrastructure and required the funds to do so.

Both Leicester and Bournemouth have long-term plans already in the process for state-of-the-art training facilities.
